message: I am planning to build a system/web app but not sure whether to use this or not.
Please share your thoughts and any decision considerations that made you move

When should you actually start thinking of using a cloud based provider like Rackspace or Amazon EC2? I see that a lot of new startups has been using either one of those technology platform in development.
i have vps-es on rackspace, and have used ec2 as well. nowadays i just deploy all of my apps to heroku ;)
we have the same app on both, & plan to abandon ec2 due to much inferior performance.
what I mean by rackspace, is the rackspace cloud
that encompasses three products: cloud servers, cloud storage, and cloud sites. so you mean cloud sites?
as I am just using this "cloud thing" for database and web api's (REST)
I mean cloud servers
@equinox Answer to your original question: When 50% of what you pay for your VPS becomes "expensive" ?

I use Rackspace Cloud Servers to run all my production apps. Never had any problems nor downtime. If i've ever needed some extra capactiy i just resize and it's sorted in a few minutes. Much cheaper than Amazon from what i've seen
maybe I'll use it and stop go daddy
is it common for people to stop their server, take a snapshot and then the following week start the server again
good
@equinox I'd say yes.
we use http://linode.com and works flawless...
we use ec2 with fab scripts to deploy new boxes when needed, never used rackspace...
why linode?
same here why linode? What's good about it?
@cdmoyer yeah .. amazon is a cloud service provider. Linode is a VPS provider
I LOVE watching the graphs :D
YOu can find half (at least) of the staff in #linode on... efnet? freenode, and they'll help you with sysadmin issues, troubles, keep you abreast of issues.
I should probably apply for their PR position, though I have a feeling  @cdmoyer will beat me to it. But either way, they are one AWESOME service.
You can get multiple servers in the same data center and not pay internal bandwidth, for building a cluster.  And the regularly just give everyone ram, disk space, etc as costs go down.
I've been using linode for 2 years, only one box, but it servers a variety of live (although low traffic projects.)
There's a couple differences, vs, say amazon.
@rigoneri totally hassle free .. cheap .. upgradable .. though probably not if you are expecting more than a million pageviews a month
not to mention their awesome library ... step by step instructions for most common scenarios
Like, it's a static VPS, so you have to worry a bit less about infrastructure and a box just going away.
and bandwidth, disk, io, etc are included so you know the price each month.
So, it's probably ideally for most projects to launch.  I mean, I always figure it's a good problem if you need to scramble and scale. ;)
And the team there is real people.
Yeah, I'm a fan.  I mean, I have clients and projects on EC2 and rackspace and mediatemple and slicehost, too.
<3 linode

personally i'm on rackspace cloud, because back in the day i think rackspace is cheaper and has better docs (i'm not a sys admin by trade) and now, i'm just too lazy to move everything. however i think now amazon giving free (although limited) for a year right? i think that should affect your choice between the 2.
it seems @cdmoyer have said everything about #linode. Just to mention that we host http://preyproject.com there, supporting millions of hit weekly. No problems so far.

@hijimayor @cdmoyer From your posts it seems that linode is a good place for small start up project, but is 4GB of ram the largest that you can get? That's probably not the best option if you are using mongodb..

interesting point @rigoneri, plus checkout the platform oriented services if you have decided on a platform, like heroku for rails, i know a couple for node.js (still in beta and not available for public yet), google appengine, etc.
@rigoneri if you are using 4GB or RAM, a VPS is already probably not for you. EC2 or rackspace would work out cheaper
